intro: Salmea scandens subsp. paraguariensis, commonly known as Paraguayan climbing salmea, is a vine native to South America, particularly Paraguay and parts of Brazil. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its climbing habit and showy, trumpet-shaped flowers. The plant produces capsule fruits that contain numerous small, oblong seeds. It thrives in humid, tropical environments and is often found in secondary forests and along riverbanks. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for ecological and horticultural study.
